Bioaccessibility and antioxidant activity of curcumin after encapsulated by nano and Pickering emulsion based on chitosan-tripolyphosphate nanoparticles

In the current study the influence of different lipid-based formulations (Pickering and nanoemulsions) and their droplet size on curcumin encapsulation and bioaccessibility, aswell as on its anti-oxidant activity was investigated. Oil-in-water Pickering emulsion stabilized by chitosan-tripolyphosphate (CS-TPP) nanoparticles and nanoemulsions containing an organic phase (Span80:Tween80), were prepared with either medium chain triglyceride (MCT) or corn oil as long chain triglyceride (LCT). An in vitro gastrointestinal (GIT) model consisting of mouth, gastric and intestinal phases was used to characterize the rate and extent of lipid phase digestion of the ingested samples. A centrifugation method determined fraction of curcumin released into mixed micelles after digestion (bioaccessibility). These findings showed that after subjecting to simulated GIT model, all the emulsion systems experienced a progressive increase in mean particle size, due to droplet flocculation and coalescence after digestion. Electrical charge (ζ) of particles was observed to become highly negative as they passed through GIT due to accumulation of anionic bile salts, phospholipids and free fatty acids at their interfaces. The rate and extent of lipid digestion and bioaccessibility of curcumin increasedwith decreasingmean droplet diameter (NMCT N NCO N PMCT N PCO). Finally, we showed that as compared to free curcumin, the encapsulated curcumin showed higher radical scavenging activity (RSA),which confirmed the protective effect of the emulsion systems on the antioxidant activity of curcumin.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Curcumin (1,7-bis(4-hydroxy-3-methoxyphenyl)-1,6-heptadiene3,5-dione; Fig. 1) is a hydrophobic polyphenol derived from the rhizome of the herb Curcuma longa, and is widely used in traditional Indian and Chinese medicines. Curcumin has been found to exert a wide range of beneficial biological and pharmacological activities including antioxidant (Sharma, 1976), anti-inflammatory (Chainani-Wu, 2003), antimicrobial (De et al., 2009) and anticancer (Aggarwal, Kumar, & Bharti, 2003). Furthermore, the hepato- and nephro-protective (Venkatesan, Punithavathi, & Arumugam, 2000), thrombosis suppressing (Srivastava, Dikshit, Srimal, & Dhawan, 1985), myocardial infarction

protective (Nirmala & Puvanakrishnan, 1996), hypoglycemic (Arun & Nalini, 2002), and antirheumatic (Deodhar, Sethi, & Srimal, 1980) effects of curcumin are also well established. However, the clinical advancement of this promising natural compound is hindered by its poor water solubility and short biological half-life, resulting in low bioavailability in both plasma and tissues. The main reasons attributing to the low bioavailability are supposed to be the poor solubility of curcumin in aqueous media, rapid hydrolysis followed by molecular fragmentation at physiological pH and inactivity of its metabolic products (Lin, Pan, & Lin-Shiau, 2000). Facing this problem, a number of attempts have been made to increase the aqueous solubility and stability and hence the bioavailability of curcumin through encapsulation of curcumin in surfactant micelles (Iwunze, 2004), phospholipids (Semalty, Semalty, Rawat, & Franceschi, 2010), cyclodextrine (Baglole, Boland, & Wagner, 2005), hydrogel (Shah, Mishra, Kumar, Priyadarsini, & Bajaj, 2008), liposomes (Letchford, Liggins, & Burt, 2008), polymeric micelles (Takahashi, Uechi, Takara, Asikin, & Wada, 2009), nanoparticles (Das, Kasoju, & Bora, 2010).
In this context emulsion based delivery systems are being used increasingly for encapsulating lipophilic bioactive compounds in food, pharmaceutical and cosmetic industry (Cheng, Decker, Xiao, &
ctivity of curcumin after encapsulated by nano and Pickering emulsion .doi.org/10.1016/j.foodres.2016.08.022
McClements, 2012). The design of these emulsions which are known to allow controlled release of the encapsulated bioactive compounds throughout gastrointestinal tract has attractedmuch attention in recent years (Shani-Levi, Levi-Tal, & Lesmes, 2013). The mostly used emulsion systems are either Pickering emulsions or nanoemulsion which can be prepared by homogenizing the oil phase (having dissolved lipophilic bioactive compound), with aqueous phase containing emulsifier. The two types of emulsions can be easily distinguished from each other based on their particle sizes as the nanoemulsions have smaller mean droplet radius (nm) than Pickering emulsion, having larger mean droplet radius (μm). As a matter of fact, after ingestion, food product is exposed to a wide range of physical and biochemical (e.g. dilution effect, pH, enzymes, bile salts, etc.) conditions as it passes through the mouth into stomach and intestines. Starting in mouth, food goes through the processing ofmixingwith saliva and air, heating or cooling to body temperature, changes in ionic strength and pH, distortion during mastication, and to salivary enzymes and biopolymers such as mucin. After mouth, food will travel to stomach through esophagus and will be mixed with gastric fluid that contains different enzymes (pepsin and gastric lipase) and electrolytes (Na+, Cl−, Ca2+ etc.) (Pal, Brasseur, & Abrahamsson, 2007).
Digestion of lipids within the gastrointestinal tract is a complex process and to date the impact on release and uptake of any encapsulated lipophilic components is not fully understood. Therefore, the in vitro digestionmodels have recently gainedmuch attention as a tool for understanding basic physicochemical processes that occur during lipid digestion and release of encapsulated components (McClements & Li, 2010). In particular, in vitro lipolysis models (“pH-stat methods”) have been developed as a powerfulmeans of quantifying lipid digestion process and release of lipophilic substances into various colloid phases formed during lipid digestion, e.g., mixed micelles (Pouton, 2006).
Due to smaller droplet sizes, nanoemulsions are considered to be more stable to particle aggregation and gravitation separation. These systems are generally employed for encapsulation of hydrophobic bioactive compounds to improve their dispersion into food products, to protect them against degradation or interaction with other ingredients, to reduce the impact on organoleptic properties of food and to improve their bioavailability (Donsi, Sessa, Mediounic, Mgaidic, & Ferrari, 2011). On the other hand, Pickering emulsions which are stabilized by solid particles have also been focused as important formulations for encapsulation of bioactive compounds in food, cosmetic and pharmaceutical industries. However, despite extensive understanding of unique physical properties of these emulsions, there is limited characterization of the in vitro digestion of bioactive compounds encapsulated in emulsions stabilized by chitosan-tripolyphosphate (CS-TPP) nanoparticles. These CS-TPP nanoparticles are formed by the ionic gelation between the positively charged primary amino groups of CS and the negatively charged groups of polyanion such as TPP, the most extensively used ion cross linking agent (Shu & Zhu, 2002). The interaction between CS and TPP needs mild conditions of temperature and pH (Zhang, Oh, Allen, & Kumacheva, 2004) and the size of the obtained NPs can be easily controlled by varying CS: TPP ratio, pH and molar mass of the CS (Tsai, Chen, Bai, & Chen, 2011). This physical cross-linking between CS and TPP avoids chemical cross linking which is not only toxic to the organism but also can damage the drugs (Berger et al., 2004).
Please cite this article as: Shah, B.R., et al., Bioaccessibility and antioxidant a based on chitosan-tripolyp..., Food Research International (2016), http://dx
The current study was aimed to evaluate the influence of carrier oil and emulsion type on the bioaccessibility of encapsulated curcumin using a simulated gastrointestinal model comprising mouth, stomach and small intestine. These results will be of great importance for designing effective delivery systems to encapsulate curcumin for application within food and pharmaceutical products.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Chitosan (CS, Mw 5 × 105–7 × 105 Da and degree of deacetylation about 90.5%) was purchased from Qingdao Yunzhou Biochemistry Co., Ltd. (Shandong, China). Medium chain triglyceride (MCT) was purchased from Boxing 145 Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Wuhan, China). Corn oil (LCT) was purchased from local supermarket. Curcumin (95.0% purity), was purchased from National Medicine Group Chemal Reagent Co., Ltd. Sodium Tripolyphosphate (TPP), glacial acetic acid, Porcine bile extracts, Tween 80, Span 80, sodium azide, ethanol, NaCl, CaCl2, NaOH and HCl were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Beijing, China). Pancreatic lipase and DPPH (1.2, and 2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. All the reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Water used in all experiments was purified by deionization and filtration with a Millipore purification apparatus (Millipore, MA, USA) to a resistivity higher than 18.0 MΩ cm.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of CS-TPP NPs
sections.text: CS-TPP NPs were prepared using the ionic gelling techniques as described in our previouswork (Shah et al., 2016). Briefly, CS solutionwas prepared by dissolving CS (0.5 wt%) powder in 0.5% acetic acid solution, whichwas further dilutedwith de-ionizedwater tomake a total volume of 200mL. Themass ratio of CS to glacial acetic acid was kept at 2:3. The resultant mixture was stirred for overnight at room temperature (around 25 °C). A solution of TPP at concentration of 1.0 mg/mL (0.1 wt%) was prepared by dissolving TPP powder in ultrapure water. Nanoparticles were then prepared by adding TPP solution drop-wise to CS solution (at CS:TPP mass ratio of 5:5) under constant stirring till the formation of an opalescent suspension that indicated particles formation.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of the curcumin encapsulated Pickering emulsion
sections.text: Curcuminwas added to the oil phase (MCT or LCT) at the concentration of 0.1 wt% and the mixture was stirred overnight with magnetic stirring to ensuremaximumdissolution to curcumin in the oil. Themixturewas then centrifuged at 14,000g for 10min to sediment the un-dissolved curcumin. The curcumin encapsulated Pickering emulsion was then achieved as described in our previous work (Shah et al., 2016). Briefly, curcumin containing oil phase (MCT or LCT) and aqueous phase (CS-TPPNPs)were taken in a glass vial. Themixturewas then homogenizedwith anUltraTurrax®T25 device equippedwith a S25N-18G shaft (IKA, Germany) rotating at a speed of 10,000 rpm for 3 min. The emulsion so formed was transferred to glass bottles and was stored at room temperature (around 25 °C) for further studies. The oil fractions in the Pickering emulsion were kept at 5 wt%.

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of the curcumin encapsulated nanoemulsion
sections.text:
Curcumin encapsulated nanoemulsion was prepared by spontaneous emulsification using the method as described by Saberi, Fang, and McClements (2013). Briefly, an organic phase was prepared by mixing nonionic surfactants (Span80:Tween80 = 1.5:8.5) and oil phase (5 wt% MCT or LCT containing 0.1 wt% curcumin) for 10 min at SOR2:1 (Surfactant Oil Ratio). Then this mixed organic phase was

added dropwise in an aqueous phase (0.02% sodium azide)with continuous stirring (200–1000 rpm) for 15min at ambient temperature using a magnetic stirrer (84-1A, Sile Instruments, China). The prepared emulsionswere stored in glass vials at room temperature for further analysis.

sections.heading: 2.5. Characterization of the NPs and the emulsion systems
sections.text: Then mean particle diameter and particle size distributions of CSTPP NPs, digesta samples of nanoemulsions and electrical charge (ζ-potential) of both the emulsion systems were determined through a dynamic light scattering instrument (Zetasizer NanoZS, Malvern® Instruments, UK). This instrument determines the particle size from intensity-time fluctuations of a laser beam (633 nm), scattered from the sample at a scattering angle of 173° at 25 °C. Each individual measurement was an average of 15 runs. Particle sizes were expressed as the z-average diameter given by the cumulant method. Whereas the mean droplet diameter and distribution of the Pickering emulsions and their digesta samples were measured by laser diffraction using a MasterSizer® 2000 granulometer (Malvern®, UK). The refractive indices of water and MCT were 1.33 and 1.45 respectively. Photographs of vials containing emulsions were taken with a Nikon digital camera (D90). Confocal fluorescencemicroscopy imageswere taken to evaluate structural changes that occurred within different phases of the GIT model. For this, first the emulsions and samples taken from GIT model were dyed with Nile red that was previously dissolved at a concentration of 0.1% (w/v) in ethanol. An equal droplet from each sample was placed on a microscope slide and was gently covered with a cover slip. Then a Nikon Confocal Microscope (Nikon D-Eclipse C1 80i, Nikon,Melville, NY) with a 40 × 10 oil immersion objective lens was used to capture the confocal images. The pH values were monitored using a pH meter (Metller Toledo FiveEasy Plus™ pH).

sections.heading: 2.6. In vitro digestion
sections.text: In order to study the in vitro digestion of curcumin, a simulated gastro intestinal (GIT) model consisting of mouth, stomach and intestine was used as previously described by (Mun & McClements, 2006). Then each of the prepared emulsion samples was exposed to these simulated environments in a queue.

sections.heading: 2.6.1. Mouth phase
sections.text: The process of the in vitro digestion was started frommouth. Firstly, simulated salivary fluid (SSF) was prepared according to a previous study (Sarkar, Goh, Singh, & Singh, 2009), which contained different salts such as sodium chloride 1.594 g/L, ammonium nitrate 0.328 g/L, potassium phosphate 0.636 g/L, potassium chloride 0.202 g/L, potassium citrate 0.308 g/L, urea 0.198 g/L, lactic acid sodium salt 0.146 g/L and Porcine gastric Mucin Type II 5 g/L. Four milliliters of the corresponding nano and Pickering emulsion (containing 5 wt% MCT) was placed in a beaker and mixed with 4 mL of simulated saliva. Then pH of the mixture was adjusted to 6.8 and shaken continuously at 100 revmin−1 in a temperature controlled incubator (37 °C) for 10min.

sections.heading: 2.6.2. Gastric phase
sections.text: Next, simulated gastric fluid (SGF) was prepared according to the method of (Sarkar et al., 2009) by dissolving 2 g of NaCl and 7 mL of HCl, with the addition of 3.2 g pepsin in 1 L of water and adjusting the pH to 1.2 using 1.0 M HCl. The “bolus” sample from the mouth phase was then mixed with SGF at a mass ration of 50:50. The mixture was then adjusted to pH 2.0 using 1MNaOH and incubatedwith continuous shaking at 100 rev min−1 at 37 °C for up to 2 h.

sections.heading: 2.6.3. Small intestinal phase
sections.text:
Finally, the simulated intestinal digestion phase was carried out by using pH-stat (907 Titrando, Metrohm, USA Inc.) device that simulates the conditions in the small intestine of the gastrointestinal tract

(McClements & Li, 2010). For this, an aliquot of 30 mL of the sample was placed in a temperature-controlled (37 °C) chamber and the pH was adjusted at 7.0 using NaOH solution. Then, 4 mL of bile extract (46.87mg/mL) and 1mL of calcium chloride (110mg/mL) solution dissolved in phosphate buffer was added to the sample and the pHwas adjusted to 7.0 if necessary. Afterwards, 1.5 mL of freshly prepared lipase suspension (at a concentration of 60 mg/mL) dissolved in phosphate buffer (PBS) was also added into the mixture. During 2 h of the intestinal digestion process, the pH of themixturewasmonitored and the volume of 0.25 M NaOH (mL) necessary to neutralize the free fatty acids (FFA) released from the lipid digestion (i.e., to maintain pH at 7.0) was noted. The following equation was used to calculate the amount of FFA released during the digestion process (Salvia-Trujillo, Qian, Martín-Belloso, & McClements, 2013).

sections.heading: 2.7. Curcumin bioaccessibility determination
sections.text:
The term bioaccessibility refers to the amount of an ingested compound dissolved in intestinal fluids in a form having capability of absorption in the intestinal lumen. The bioaccessibility of curcumin in the nano and Pickering emulsions was determined after the in vitro digestion process using amethod described previously (Cheng et al., 2012). An aliquot of the raw digestawas centrifuged at 16,000 rpm for 30min at 4 °C. The middle transparent layer was taken to be the “micelle fraction” in which the curcumin was solubilized. 5 mL micelle fraction was mixed with 5 mL ethanol, vortexed and centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 10 min at 25 °C. The top layer with the solubilized curcumin was collected while the bottom layer was mixed with 5 mL of ethanol and the same procedure was repeated. The top ethanol layer was added to the previous one and the absorbance was measured at 425 nm using a spectrophotometer (UV-1100, Meipuda Instrument, China). Pure ethanol was used as a reference. The curcumin concentration from a sample was determined by a previously prepared calibration curve. The bioaccessibility was then calculated using the following equation:
Bioaccessibility %ð Þ ¼ Cmicelle Cdigesta 100
where, Cmicelle and Cdigesta are the concentrations of curcumin in the micelle fraction and in the overall sample (rawdigesta) after the pH-stat experiment, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.8. Antioxidant activity evaluation of curcumin
sections.text:
Antioxidant activities of the encapsulated curcumin were evaluated through a free radical-scavenging effect of stable DPPH•, as described by (Yang, Wu, Li, Zhou & Wang, 2013). Briefly, 0.004% (4 mg) DPPH• was dissolved in ethanol which was designated as a pure DPPH• solution. For radical scavenging activity (RSAs) determination, pure DPPH• solution was added to each sample in 1:1 ratio. Similarly, control was prepared by adding pure DPPH• solution to solvent in 1:1 ratio. And finally, the blank solutionwas prepared by adding the sample to the solvent (ethanol)withoutDPPH• solution in ratio of 1:1. All of the prepared samples were shaken vigorously and were kept in dark for an incubation period of 45 min. The RSAs assay was carried out by recording the absorbance of samples containing DPPH• at 517 nm in the presence and absence of the remnant curcumin at room temperature with a

UV–vis spectrophotometer. The antioxidant activity of curcumin was assessed by the percentage of DPPH• that was decreased in comparison with that of the control condition after 45 min preservation in the dark. The following equation was used to calculate the RSAs for each sample.

where Asample, Ablank and Acontrol are the absorbance of sample, blank and control solutions respectively.

sections.heading: 2.9. Statistical analysis
sections.text: All measurements were performed in triplicates and presented as means and standard deviations. Statistical analysis was performed by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) using SPSS18.0 software. Comparisons between sample means were evaluated using LSD test at 5% level of significance.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of oil type on emulsion characteristics in digestion model
sections.text:
Initially, we evaluated the influence of oil type on the physical stability and electrical characteristics of the particles in curcumin encapsulated emulsion systems (nano and Pickering). A series of oil-in-water nano andCS-TPPNPs stabilized Pickering emulsion systems, containing 5wt% MCT or LCT and 0.1 wt% curcumin were prepared as described in Sections 2.3 and 2.4. The mean particle size (Z-average diameters) of the initial samples and of samples collected after different stages of the simulated gastrointestinal model was monitored. As a matter of fact, the main aim of the emulsion system encapsulating a bioactive compound is to protect it from the harsh influence of gastric environment. Such desirable results were obtained in the current study. As determined by light scattering, non-significant increase in the mean particle diameter after exposure to artificial saliva and simulated gastric fluid was noted (Fig. 2), which can be attributed to the good physical stability of the emulsion systems. This phenomenon of the stable emulsion system was supported by the fact that a relatively strong steric repulsion was generated by the neutral hydrophilic head groups of the non-ionic surfactants used to stabilize the nanoemulsion, as the simulated oral and gastric fluids didn't contain any highly surface active
Please cite this article as: Shah, B.R., et al., Bioaccessibility and antioxidant a based on chitosan-tripolyp..., Food Research International (2016), http://dx
compounds. Similar results have been reported by Nik, Langmaid, and Wright (2012) that lipids droplets coated by non-ionic surfactants are comparatively stable to the influence of simulated oral and gastric environments. Whereas, after exposure to the simulated small intestinal fluids, all the emulsions showed appreciable increase in mean particle diameter indicating that they were unstable to aggregation. For example, themean particle diameter of the corn oil nano and Pickering emulsion increased from 109 to 1221 nm and 18.8 to 86.4 μm respectively (Fig. 2), showing reduction in the physical stability of the emulsion in the small intestine environment. Several factors were thought to be responsible for this transition in the mean particle diameter. First, the non-ionic surfactant molecules originally adsorbed to the lipid droplet surfaces may have been displaced by other surface active species in the system, such as phospholipids, bile salts and lipase (present in the simulated gastrointestinal fluids) or free fatty acids and monoacylglycerols (generated by lipase digestion of triacylglycerols) resulting a change in the composition, structure and properties of the interfacial layer surrounding the lipid droplets which may have led to a decrease in their coalescence stability. Secondly, emulsified digestible triacylglycerols (i.e., LCT and MCT) are converted to free fatty acids and monoacylglycerols in the presence of adsorbed lipases thereby altering the internal composition, structure and properties of the lipid droplets which may also have decreased their coalescence stability (Cheng, Decker, Xiao, & McClements, 2012). Herein, we also measured the electrical characteristics (ζ) of the particles in the initial emulsions and of samples collected after each digestion step (Fig. 3). Interestingly, we found appreciable variation in the electrical properties of the particles in the initial emulsions (both nano and Pickering) depending on carrier oil. And were found to be: ζ ≈ −12.84 ± 1.3, 13.17 ± 3.7 for corn oil and –4.26± 1.005, 6.17± 1.77 forMCT in nano and Pickering emulsion respectively. Generally, it is believed that neutral lipid droplets stabilized by a non-ionic surfactant would carry little electrical charge. However, due to possibility of the presence of anionic impurities within surfactant or lipid phase that could adsorb to the oil-water interface, may contribute a negative charge on the droplets e.g. free fatty acids and phospholipids (Cheng et al., 2012). It has also been reported that small anionic ions (such as OH−) in water may preferentially adsorb to oil-water interfaces and contribute negative charge under neutral conditions (Hsu & Nacu, 2003). Whereas, such phenomenon couldn't be seen in case of Pickering emulsion which was stabilized by CS-TPP nanoparticles, and therefore, the emulsion initially had positive electrical charge for both type of oils i.e. corn oil andMCT.However, changes in

fatty acids that tend to accumulate at oil-water interfaces, whereasMCT contains medium chain fatty acids that tend to move into the aqueous phase (Sek, Boyd, Charman, & Porter, 2006).
The droplet size distribution of the different emulsion systems showed that initially they had almost monomodal distribution. However, after digestion, all the emulsions exhibited large increase in mean particle size (Fig. 2) and the particle size distribution changed from monomodal to bimodal, suggesting that these droplets were unstable to aggregation (Fig. 4c). These observations were further validated by characterizing changes in the emulsions droplet size through fluorescence confocal microscopy. The images in Fig. 5, clearly showed that the nanoemulsions contained much finer droplets than the Pickering emulsions and therefore, it was difficult to distinguish the individual droplets in the nanoemulsions because they are close to the limit of resolution of the optical microscope. However, after incubation in the mouth and gastric, the individual fluorescent spherical structures of emulsion systems were transformed to elongated structures which can be clearly seen in case of Pickering emulsions (Fig. 5). These elongated irregular clusters of oil droplets observed after exposure the simulated mouth and gastric phases indicated the particles aggregation. The previous studies stated that this aggregation can be attributed to the depletion and/or bridging flocculation caused by droplet interactions with mucin (Sarkar et al., 2009). In bridging flocculation, mucin acts as a bridge that simultaneously binds to the surfaces of two or more droplets causing the droplets to aggregate (Singh, Ye, & Horne, 2009). Contrary, depletion flocculation occurs due to the presence of sufficiently high levels of non-adsorbed polymer (mucin) molecules in the aqueous phase surrounding the droplets (Silletti, Vingerhoeds, Norde, & vanAken, 2007). As it is evident in Fig. 5 that in the small intestine stage there appeared to be a fairly even distribution of lipid-rich particles that are likely to be the digestion products generated by lipase-induced breakdown of triacylglycerol molecules, such as mixed
micelles, vesicles and other colloidal structures, as well as any nondigested fat droplets (Salvia-Trujillo et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of oil and emulsion type on in vitro lipid digestion
sections.text:
The effect of oil phase aswell as emulsion type on the rate and extent of lipid digestionwasmeasured using the pH-stat method. Two types of emulsion i.e. nano and Pickering containing curcumin in the oil phase were prepared with corn oil and MCT. The volume of NaOH (0.2 M) required for titration to maintain a constant pH (7.0) was measured as a function of digestion time with the help of which the amount of free fatty acids (FFAs) released from the oil phase (corn oil and MCT) was calculated. As can be seen in Fig. 6, initially there was a progressive increase in the amount of NaOH that needed to be added to the emulsion samples, after which a relatively constant value was reached. Comparing the oil type, it was found that the nature of the carrier oil type had a major impact on the kinetics of the lipid digestion (Fig. 6a). And the amount of FFAs released gradually increased with the passage of digestion was related to the carrier oil and emulsion type. For example, after 2 h of digestion, the FFAs released were 153% for NMCT (nanoemulsion with MCT) and 112% of NCO (nanoemulsion with corn oil) respectively (Fig. 6). Previous literatures have stated that there can be different reasons for this high (N100%) final FFAs released for MCT systems. First, theremight have been some conversion ofmonoacylglycerols into glycerol and FFAs whichwas not taken into account in the calculations. Second, there may have been other components in the systems that were hydrolysed and contributed to the pH statmeasurements, such as phospholipids, proteins, or surfactants in the digestion medium (Li, Hu, & McClements, 2011). It is also believed that medium chain fatty acids are able to migrate rapidly to the surrounding aqueous phase; whereas, long chain fatty acids tend to accumulate at the oil–water interface and therefore inhibit lipase activity, which would account for the observed
he emulsion systems as determined by confocal fluorescence microscopy.
Fig. 6. Influence of carrier oil and emulsion type on the a) percentage of free fatty acids released in vitro digestion, b) bioaccessibility of curcumin.
decrease in digestibility at high LCT levels (Dahan & Hoffman, 2008). Similar results were also reported by (Ahmed, Li, McClements, & Xiao, 2012; Li et al., 2011).
In comparison to nanoemulsion, itwas found that the rate of FFAs released was much slower from the Pickering emulsion. And after 2 h of digestion, the FFAs released was noted to be 60% and 34% for PMCT (Pickering emulsion with MCT) and PCO (Pickering emulsion with corn oil) respectively (Fig. 6a). These results clearly show that the amount of fatty acids released from the CS-TPP nanoparticles stabilized Pickering emulsions was much smaller than that released from the nanoemulsions for both types of carrier oils. The phenomenon can be attributed to the fact that chitosan loses most of its positive charge at higher pH values, because the cationic functional groups (\\NH3+) on chitosan have a pKa value around pH 6.5 (Shahidi, Arachchi, & Jeon, 1999). Presumably, at pH 7 the pancreatic lipase could not get access to the lipids within the large chitosan aggregates. And hence it can be concluded that chitosan is capable of reducing the digestibility of emulsified lipids.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of oil and emulsion type on in vitro bioaccessibility
sections.text:
The effect of oil phase and emulsion type on bioaccessibility of curcumin in both the nano and Pickering emulsion was determined by measuring curcumin concentrations in the micelle phase and in overall digesta. The emulsion samples after digestionswere centrifuged and the transparent micelle phase was collected. The obtained results showed that the bioaccessibility of curcumin was clearly depended on the carrier oil and emulsion type (Fig. 6b). Despite the fact that the triacylglycerols in both MCT and LCT nanoemulsions were almost fully digested, there were major differences in curcumin bioaccessibility. The measured bioaccessibility was around 32% in the MCT nanoemulsions but around 65% in the LCT nanoemulsions. (Fig. 6b). It was believed that in both systems therewould be expected to be a relatively high amount of free fatty acids present, but the nature and physicochemical properties of the FFA are quite different. The phenomenon can be further explained by the fact that long chain fatty acids tend to form micelles than medium chain fatty acids, and the micelles formed have a larger solubilization capacity due to the larger dimensions of their hydrophobic core (Cheng et al., 2012). Findings of our study are also in close agreement with previous studies in the pharmaceutical industry showing that many highly lipophilic drugs have a higher bioaccessibility when LCT is used as a carrier oil rather thanMCT in lipid-based delivery systems (Kossena, Boyd, Porter, & Charman, 2003). It is obvious that comparing to the nanoemulsion, curcumin bioaccessibility was lower in the Pickering emulsion for both types of oil phases. The reason for this can be presented as the extent of lipid digestion in these emulsionswas slow and almost incomplete. And therefore, curcumin might be trapped within the non-digested oil droplets, thus inhibiting its incorporation into mixed micelles and ultimately lowering its bioaccessibility (Nik, Corredig, & Wright, 2011).

sections.heading: 3.4. Radical scavenging (antioxidant) activities of curcumin
sections.text:
Curcumin is known as one of the potent antioxidant agents. Therefore, to further confirm this, finally we determined free radical scavenging ability of curcumin usingDPPH radicalwhich reactswith an electron or hydrogen donor to become a stable diamagneticmolecule viz. hydrazine. The % radical scavenging activity (RSA) of curcumin encapsulated in the emulsion systems (either nano or Pickering emulsion) was compared with free curcumin dissolved in oil phase (corn oil or MCT) both before and after the in vitro digestion to know the protective effect of nano and Pickering emulsion on the antioxidant activity of curcumin. The results showed that the % RSA for nanoemulsion prepared with MCT (NMCT), Pickering emulsion with MCT (PMCT), nanoemulsion with corn oil (NCO) and Pickering emulsion with corn oil (PCO) before digestion were 29.80± 2.3, 35.18± 0.54, 37.03± 3.5 and 49.58± 2.32 respectively, whereas after the in vitro digestion the %RSA for these samples were 13.31 ± 2.11, 14.89 ± 5.5, 18.83 ± 4.22 and 15.96 ± 0.70 respectively. However, the %RSA for un-encapsulated (free) curcumin dissolved in MCT and corn oil before and after the in vitro digestion were 12.21 ± 0.51, 15.41 ± 0.69, and 4.06 ± 0.50, 6.65 ± 0.25 respectively, which were significantly lower (p b 0.05) as compared to the curcumin encapsulated in the emulsion systems (Table 1). This clearly confirms the protective effect of the emulsion systems on the antioxidant activity of curcumin and thus helped in enhancing its antioxidant potential significantly. Similar results have also been reported by many researchers who used different formulation for curcumin encapsulation aiming to enhance its antioxidant activity (Adriana, Amparo, Guadalupe, Laura, & Sandra, 2015; Parth, Ameta, & Man, 2014). One research group recently prepared curcumin encapsulated cationic triblock copolymer micelles and determined its antioxidant activity. Their results showed that the ability of the micellar curcumin to scavenge the free radical was higher than that of the free curcumin (Yoncheva et al., 2015).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In the current study, curcumin encapsulated nano and CS-TPP nanoparticles stabilized Pickering emulsions were prepared with MCT and corn oil as oil phases. These results concluded that therewas an increase in particle size after exposure to simulated GIT model comprising of mouth, stomach, and small intestine conditions for all emulsions, which can be attributed to flocculation, coalescence, and digestion. After the digestion process, the particles were highly negatively charged, which was attributed to the presence of anionic bile salts, phospholipids, and free fatty acids. The rate and extent of lipid digestion in a simulated GIT model was found to be depended on carrier oil and emulsion type. Pickering emulsions showed slow rate of digestion and thus the amount of FFAs released was lower from these emulsions as compared to nanoemulsions. Similarly, the bioaccessibility also showed the same trend and was found to be depended on the carrier oil and emulsion type and Pickering emulsions showed low bioaccessibility values for curcumin which is related to the slower digestion rate of these emulsions. The bioaccessibilitymeasured for curcuminwashigher in the emulsions with LCT than with MCT, which was attributed to the fact that the mixed micelles formed by LCT have high hydrophobic cores than those formed by MCT and therefore, they are able to trap large curcumin molecules. Finally, we determined the antioxidant potential of the encapsulated curcumin in these emulsion systems and it was found that compared to free curcumin, the encapsulated curcumin showed higher radical scavenging activity, which confirmed the protective effect of the emulsion systems on antioxidant activity of curcumin.
